<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 730, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[489, 42, 507, 58]]<|/det|>
## 2  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 640, 528]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 564, 168, 580]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 596, 320, 613]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 648, 250, 665]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 680, 151, 696]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 721, 339, 739]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 759, 207, 775]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 791, 228, 807]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 826, 238, 843]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel

\[g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{-2}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 129, 640, 149]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 160, 625, 180]]<|/det|>
\[e = 1.60\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 191, 630, 211]]<|/det|>
\[1 \mathrm{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 222, 630, 243]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 253, 630, 273]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 284, 645, 305]]<|/det|>
\[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 315, 630, 335]]<|/det|>
\[R = 8.31\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 345, 640, 365]]<|/det|>
\[k = 1.38\times 10^{-23}\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 375, 687, 396]]<|/det|>
\[G = 6.67\times 10^{-11}\mathrm{N m}^2\mathrm{kg}^{-2}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 406, 650, 465]]<|/det|>
\[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{-12}\mathrm{Fm}^{-1}\] \[\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]

\[h = 6.63\times 10^{-34}\mathrm{Js}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 504, 685, 524]]<|/det|>
\[\sigma = 5.67\times 10^{-8}\mathrm{Wm}^{-2}\mathrm{K}^{-4}\]

\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 647, 549, 666]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 676, 541, 695]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 707, 555, 744]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{V\pm V_{s}}\]

\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 787, 606, 807]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 817, 613, 852]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A well has a depth of \(36\mathrm{m}\) from ground level to the surface of the water in the well, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 112, 732, 299]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 314, 591, 334]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 362, 920, 412]]<|/det|>
A student wishes to find the depth of the well. The student plans to drop a stone down the well and record the time taken from releasing the stone to hearing the splash made by the stone as it enters the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 424, 144, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 424, 811, 443]]<|/det|>
Assume that air resistance is negligible and that the stone is released from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 454, 888, 473]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time taken for the stone to fall from ground level to the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 670, 920, 689]]<|/det|>
<form>time = .................................................... s [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 834, 89]]<|/det|> The time recorded by the student using a stop-watch is not equal to the time in **(a)**. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 890, 120]]<|/det|> Suggest **three** possible reasons, other than the effect of air resistance, for this difference. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 171, 152]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 917, 183]]<|/det|>
2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 201, 917, 218]]<|/det|>
3
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 303, 920, 322]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 146, 352]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 920, 368]]<|/det|> The student repeats the experiment three times and uses the results to calculate the depth of the well. The values are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 381, 539, 399]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 412, 781, 469]]<|/det|>
1st experiment2nd experiment3rd experiment
depth/m54.453.954.1
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 920, 515]]<|/det|> The true depth of the well is \(36.0 \text{m}\). Explain why these results may be described as precise but not accurate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 623, 920, 641]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 654, 920, 672]]<|/det|> [Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

21% of the volume of the sphere is below the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 342, 450, 361]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 514, 910, 533]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 227]]<|/det|>
A firework is initially stationary. It explodes into three fragments A, B and C that move in a horizontal plane, as shown in the view from above in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 235, 714, 477]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 500, 532, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 900, 549]]<|/det|>
Fragment A has a mass of \(3m\) and moves away from the explosion at a speed of \(4.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 562, 920, 594]]<|/det|>
Fragment B has a mass of \(2m\) and moves away from the explosion at a speed of \(6.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at right angles to the direction of A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 609, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
Fragment C has a mass of \(m\) and moves away from the explosion at a speed \(v\) and at an angle \(\theta\) as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 655, 243, 672]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 686, 183, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

the angle \(\theta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 839, 920, 857]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) .................................................... <sup>[3]</sup>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 299, 88]]<|/det|>
the speed \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 209, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
<form>v = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 210, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 144, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 920, 290]]<|/det|>
The firework in **(b)** contains a chemical that has mass \(5.0 \text{g}\) and has chemical energy per unit mass \(700 \text{J} \text{kg}^{-1}\). When the firework explodes, all of the chemical energy is transferred to the kinetic energy of fragments A, B and C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 181, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 304, 677, 322]]<|/det|>
Show that the total chemical energy in the firework is 3.5 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 412, 180, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 412, 381, 429]]<|/det|>
Calculate the mass \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 597, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................... $kg$

<mark>[3]

<mark>[Total: 11]

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 668, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
A loudspeaker, microphone and cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO) are arranged as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 210, 792, 307]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 327, 532, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 359, 920, 393]]<|/det|>
The loudspeaker is emitting a sound wave which is detected by the microphone and displayed on the screen of the CRO as shown in Fig. 4.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 403, 764, 700]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 720, 532, 738]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 750, 856, 769]]<|/det|>
The time-base on the CRO is set to \(0.50 \text{ms} \text{cm}^{-1}\) and the \(y\)-gain is set to \(0.20 \text{V} \text{cm}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 243, 87]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 180, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 465, 120]]<|/det|>
the frequency of the sound wave

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = .................................................... Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 272, 180, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 598, 291]]<|/det|>
the amplitude of the signal received by the CRO.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<form>amplitude = .................................................... V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 144, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
The intensity of the sound wave in **(b)** is reduced to a quarter of its original intensity without a change in frequency. Assume that the amplitude of the signal received by the CRO is proportional to the amplitude of the sound wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 752, 491]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 4.2, sketch the trace that is now seen on the screen of the CRO.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 473, 920, 491]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 838, 89]]<|/det|>
A metal sheet is now placed in front of the loudspeaker in **(b)**, as shown in Fig. 4.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 102, 892, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 291, 534, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 323, 771, 341]]<|/det|>
A stationary wave is formed between the loudspeaker and the metal sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 354, 181, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 354, 487, 371]]<|/det|>
State the principle of superposition.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 477, 180, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 477, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
The initial position of the microphone is such that the trace on the CRO has an amplitude minimum. It is now moved a distance of \(1.05\mathrm{m}\) away from the loudspeaker along the line joining the loudspeaker and metal sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 540, 920, 588]]<|/det|>
As the microphone moves, it passes through three positions where the trace has an amplitude maximum before ending at a position where the trace has an amplitude minimum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 602, 574, 618]]<|/det|>
Determine the wavelength of the sound wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 761, 920, 778]]<|/det|>
<form>wavelength = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 881, 89]]<|/det|>
Use your answers in (b)(i) and (d)(ii) to determine the speed of the sound in the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 230, 920, 248]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 262, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 13]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student sets up a circuit with a battery, an ammeter, a heater and a light-dependent resistor (LDR) all in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 494, 135]]<|/det|>
The battery has negligible internal resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 148, 611, 166]]<|/det|>
A voltmeter is connected across (in parallel with) the heater.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 146, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 662, 199]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.1, complete the circuit diagram of this arrangement.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 212, 559, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 415, 532, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 446, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 477, 146, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 477, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
The heater is a wire made of metal of resistivity \(1.1 \times 10^{- 6} \Omega \text{m}\). The wire has length \(2.0 \text{m}\) and cross-sectional area \(3.8 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 463, 541]]<|/det|>
The reading on the voltmeter is 4.8V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 555, 243, 572]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 180, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 586, 423, 604]]<|/det|>
the resistance of the heater

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[479, 740, 920, 758]]<|/det|>
<form>resistance = .................................................... $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 880, 920, 898]]<|/det|>
<form>reading on ammeter = .................................................... A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 880, 920, 898]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The heater is replaced by a new wire. The new wire is made of the same metal as the wire in (b) and has the same length but a larger diameter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 118, 526, 135]]<|/det|>
The resistance of the LDR remains constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 181, 166]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the new wire has a resistance that is greater than, less than or the same as that of the wire in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 288, 180, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the new reading on the voltmeter is greater than, less than or equal to 4.8V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 428, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
